person.note: American artist known for her work in the Impressionist movement and advocacy for women artists.

American art curator and administrator. He served as director of the Carnegie Museum of Art and played a key role in organizing the Carnegie International exhibitions. He corresponded with Mary Cassatt regarding acquisitions and exhibitions, indicating his influence in shaping museum collections and public taste.

French Impressionist artist famous for his pastel drawings and oil paintings. Although Degas is regarded as one of the founders of Impressionism, he rejected the term, preferring to be called a realist,and Edgar Degas and Mary Cassatt developed a deep artistic friendship after he invited her to exhibit with the Impressionists in 1879. They shared a passion for modern subjects and collaborated on printmaking.Cassatt acknowledge Degas's influence on her art.
Wife of Homer Saint-Gaudens, also friend with Mary Cassatt.

French painter and a prominent member of the Impressionist circle in Paris. French critic Gustave Geffroy grouped her alongside Mary Cassatt and Marie Bracquemond as one of the "three great ladies of Impressionism." She was a close friend of the Impressionist painter Édouard Manet, and married Eugène Manet. Their relationship created a close bond of both artistic collaboration and family ties among the Impressionist group.

org.note: Durand-Ruel was a prominent Parisian art gallery in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, known for exhibiting and supporting Impressionist artists such as Monet, Renoir, and Cassatt. The painting mentioned in this letter was exhibited there before being acquired by the Carnegie Institute.

Founded in 1895 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, the Carnegie Institute, Museum of Art was one of the first American museums devoted to contemporary art. Homer Saint-Gaudens served as director of the museum during the early 20th century, overseeing acquisitions and exhibitions. Mary Cassatt's letter to him in 1922 discusses a painting he had purchased for the museum and conveys her reflections on the work's reception by Degas and others. This letter now forms part of: Carnegie Institute, Museum of Art records, 1883-1962, bulk 1885-1962.

div.p:
I have taken refuge here from
the gloom of Paris & I suppose you
and Mrs. Saint-Gaudens are there. I regret
I shall not have the pleasure of seeing
you. I hope your committee has found
you some good things, but they are
a Jury.

It may interest you to know
what Degas said when he saw the
picture you have just bought for your
Museum.It was painted in 1891,
in the summer. and Degas come to see me

after he had seen it at Durand-Rueles
He was chary of praise but he spoke
of the drawing of the woman's arm picking
the fruit and made a familiar gesture
indicating the line & said no woman
has a right to draw like that.
He said the color was like a (?) which was not my opinion. He had spoken of
the picture to Berthe Morisot who did not like it. I can undetstand that. If it had been
the best line and as weel as well drawn
its place in a Museum might show the present generation that
we worked and learnt out profession, which isn't a bad thing.

I hope you had a pleasant time in Rome. My best wishes
to you and Mrs.Saint-Gaudens for the coming year. May it bring you
all this troubled world can give of good.
